div.p: Reconciliation is a national project.
This is part of ensuring that Canada
is a fair and inclusive country.
It means learning about our history,
learning about what we have gone through.
It is very important for people to learn about it
so that people get a sense of our history
because we are not in the Canadian history books.
To me, reconciliation starts with me.
Our history is not as peaceful, as graceful, as I was taught.
I need to recognize that I don't know everything
and I am ready to learn.
The opportunities for reconciliation are everywhere.
We are a huge instrument of public governance
in this country, and so it is especially important for us
to find a way that we can translate concepts like
reconciliation into practical, meaningful change on the ground
in the lives of Indigenous peoples.
This is not a scary concept.
It is not an incantation for political purposes.
This is truly about our mission to help build a better Canada.
It is about developing that knowledge
of what our history was.
We took away cultural identities from people.
We promoted these types of soul wounds, and we didn't allow them
the space to be and to identify with who they are as people.
We didn't encourage their language.
We didn't encourage their cultural ways.
Our early history is not solid.
It is a dark history, and we are still trying
to move past some of the actions that we took over 100 years ago.
Sessions like this are really important,
particularly at the executive level.
A conference like this, with executives in
the public service, is really critical to have
a session on reconciliation.
The commitment is exemplified from the top.
It has a ripple effect throughout the sector
through the department, throughout public service.
I am hoping that, through these sessions,
people will learn about who we are.
Hopefully people will take an interest,
not just because it is their job and because these are
people's lives that we are dealing with.
I hope they take it out of interest and also for
their professional development, so that they can make
a better informed decision on behalf of the people they serve.
The Indigenous identity is one of the distinguishing features
that makes us Canadians.
It is hard-wired into our history as Canada.
So I think it is important that each of us takes
personal responsibility to learn about our own history,
to acknowledge the place that Indigenous people
have had in the past, but even more important,
who they are today and what place they will have
going forward.
I am hoping that we have developed a relationship
where there is mutual respect.
We cannot expect it to be within a day,
within a week, within a month.
It is something that we have to work on, on a daily basis.
It is not one department's job. It is not one individual's job.
Reconciliation is going to be all of our jobs.
